Attributing Cyberattacks

1999-2009

Legal

TEsting

this is better

Jurisdiction

The problem is compounded by the observation that attribution efforts frequently require cross‑border access and sensitive forensics—steps that may themselves implicate other states' jurisdiction—so timely, conclusive attribution is often infeasible ((Joyner, 2001, p. 27)(Todd, 2009, p. 36)(Johnson, 2002, p. 7)).

Evidentiary failure

In practice the evidentiary shortfall is not merely academic: researchers traced espionage hosts to a country but explicitly \"cautioned against concluding\" government involvement, showing how technical nuance converts into legal ambiguity ((Franzese, 2009, p. 4)(Kodar, 2009, p. 10)(Schaap, 2009, p. 27)).

Self-defense

Legal commentators converge on a strong regularity: established jus ad bellum requirements—necessity, imminence, and proportionality—implicitly require reliable attribution before a state can lawfully employ force, and cyber operations routinely fail to produce that degree of proof. Multiple sources assert that the law of self‑defence \"does not justify acts of active defense across international borders unless the provocation can be attributed to an agent of the nation concerned\" and that discerning hostile intent is an additional evidentiary burden that cyber incidents often cannot meet quickly ((Hoisington, 2009, p. 14)(Joyner, 2001, p. 27)(Hoisington, 2009, p. 14)). The legal consequence is that many potentially serious CNAs fall short of the evidentiary threshold for force, producing a governance gap where operations may be harmful yet not legally actionable under present doctrine.

Burden of proof lowering

Scholars debate doctrinal remedies—some recommend lowering the burden by emphasizing state due diligence rather than a strict state‑actor link, while others reject relaxed thresholds as likely to cause mis‑signalling. Proponents of a due‑diligence approach argue that \"state responsibility must be based on a due diligence requirement\" and that obligations to investigate and prevent operations originating in a state's territory could reduce impunity ((Kulesza, 2009, p. 13)(Kulesza, 2009, p. 13)(Kodar, 2009, p. 10)). Critics counter that relaxing attribution rules risks wrongful coercion because countermeasures against conduits or intermediaries may be \"counterproductive, as well as unlawful,\" and that erroneous or premature responses could escalate conflicts ((Dinstein, 2002, p. 9)(Jensen, 2002, p. 27)(Smith, 2002, p. 13)).

Policy

False-flags

Military and doctrinal writings acknowledge deliberate deception—\"forging the information in the enemy's reconnaissance database\"—which raises false‑flag risks and confirms that some IO tactics are designed to thwart attribution ((Kodar, 2009, p. 17)(Hollis, 2007, p. 9)(Jensen, 2002, p. 29)).

Timing

The problem is compounded by the observation that attribution efforts frequently require cross‑border access and sensitive forensics—steps that may themselves implicate other states' jurisdiction—so timely, conclusive attribution is often infeasible ((Joyner, 2001, p. 27)(Todd, 2009, p. 36)(Johnson, 2002, p. 7)).

Assimetry

The literature also documents a widening actor set and a diffusion of capability that further complicate attribution. Scholars note that offensive tools are cheap and widely accessible so actors range from states to ideological groups, criminals, and lone individuals, increasing plausible deniability and blurring categories of responsibility ((Jensen, 2002, p. 8)(Kodar, 2009, p. 9)(Dinstein, 2002, p. 9)).

non-state actors

Multiple case‑based accounts illustrate these technical constraints in practice and show how ambiguous traces are politically contestable. Reviews of high‑profile events find forensic indicators that point to third‑party hosts or IP blocks but stop short of proving state direction; commentators caution that traffic traced to machines in a state does not prove governmental control and that investigators can be \"unable to trace these activities back\" to a state's military or bureaucracy ((Kodar, 2009, p. 12)(Franzese, 2009, p. 3)(Johnson, 2002, p. 4)).

Several authors describe attackers who \"can remain anonymous or even disguise an attack's origins\" and note that apparent sources are often merely conduits manipulated by third parties, which makes swift counter‑measures legally risky ((Hollis, 2007, p. 10)(Dinstein, 2002, p. 9)(Hoisington, 2009, p. 15)).

Technical Attribution

Anonimity

Several authors describe attackers who \"can remain anonymous or even disguise an attack's origins\" and note that apparent sources are often merely conduits manipulated by third parties, which makes swift counter‑measures legally risky ((Hollis, 2007, p. 10)(Dinstein, 2002, p. 9)(Hoisington, 2009, p. 15)).

Limitations

In practice the evidentiary shortfall is not merely academic: researchers traced espionage hosts to a country but explicitly \"cautioned against concluding\" government involvement, showing how technical nuance converts into legal ambiguity ((Franzese, 2009, p. 4)(Kodar, 2009, p. 10)(Schaap, 2009, p. 27)).

The Attribution Problem

Attribution is impossible or very difficult

The problem is compounded by the observation that attribution efforts frequently require cross‑border access and sensitive forensics—steps that may themselves implicate other states' jurisdiction—so timely, conclusive attribution is often infeasible ((Joyner, 2001, p. 27)(Todd, 2009, p. 36)(Johnson, 2002, p. 7)).

Multiple case‑based accounts illustrate these technical constraints in practice and show how ambiguous traces are politically contestable. Reviews of high‑profile events find forensic indicators that point to third‑party hosts or IP blocks but stop short of proving state direction; commentators caution that traffic traced to machines in a state does not prove governmental control and that investigators can be \"unable to trace these activities back\" to a state's military or bureaucracy ((Kodar, 2009, p. 12)(Franzese, 2009, p. 3)(Johnson, 2002, p. 4))

Findings

Legal cooperations gaps create obstacles

Because decisive attribution often depends on cross‑border evidence and intelligence sharing, legal cooperation gaps create additional obstacles: absent extradition treaties or mutual‑assistance norms, states may lack legal mechanisms to compel evidence or to hold perpetrators to account, shifting the burden away from attribution and toward diplomatic remedies ((Kodar, 2009, p. 18)(Kodar, 2009, p. 20)(Hollis, 2007, p. 5)). Analysts therefore emphasize international investigative cooperation as a partial remedy—\"effective international cooperation in tracing computer network attacks\" could \"greatly expedite attribution\"—but they also note that political will and legal harmonization are prerequisites ((Johnson, 2002, p. 7)(Hollis, 2007, p. 29)(Johnson, 2002, p. 5)).

Techinical evidence is not enough

Case studies repeatedly show how technical uncertainty becomes a diplomatic flashpoint: Estonia's 2007 episode is narrated in several pieces as a situation where forensic indicators (e.g., domains and servers) were used to implicate a foreign government while the accused party denied state involvement and at times pointed to civilian or volunteer initiatives, highlighting how ambiguous evidence translates into contested political narratives ((Schaap, 2009, p. 25)(Kulesza, 2009, p. 3)(Joyner, 2001, p. 18)). These passages show that attribution failures do not merely reduce clarity; they actively create political divergence over legal obligations and proportional responses.

this is a test

Gaps

2010-2018

Attribution issues

Technical

Many commentators argue that meeting necessity and proportionality demands will often be “exceedingly difficult” absent high confidence in attribution (Gill, 2013, p. 30)

Several authors characterise attribution as practically infeasible in many cases (Hobe, 2018, p. 12), link the problem to cyberspace’s “three specific attributes” (anonymity, staged operations, speed) (Baradaran, 2017, p. 8), and situate these dynamics in a doctrinal framing that highlights how conventional tests rely on human‑ or organ‑level connections that networks rarely disclose (Tsagourias, 2012, p. 5).

Forensic practice supplies a consistent empirical finding: technical traces more often point to devices, servers, or code patterns than to accountable human operators, and this evidentiary gap is decisive in criminal and civil enforcement. Case notes document public technical dossiers that remain largely circumstantial and insufficient for courtroom standards (Shull, 2016), and reviewers stress that prosecution depends on linking acts to identifiable offenders, which is hard in botnet or spoofing scenarios (Kaiser, 2015, p. 9). Technical constraints—IP‑spoofing, hijacked intermediaries, and the device/location problem—mean countermeasures risk striking proxies or innocents rather than perpetrators (Roscini, 2010, p. 30), creating a regular link between forensic complexity and uneven enforcement.

Timing

Empirical descriptions emphasise that traces often require “days, weeks, months or even years” to follow up (Gaul, 2013, p. 48),

definitive answers can take months, compressing windows for lawful countermeasures (Swanson, 2010, p. 18).

jurisdiction

that distributed campaigns produce artefacts in many jurisdictions (O'Connell, 2012, p. 20),

Institutional fragmentation and capacity asymmetries recurrently compound technical limits: cross‑border evidence collection is hindered by overlapping laws and by states with weak detection capabilities, while datasets and public reporting bias visibility toward already‑attributable incidents. Authors document a “morass” of national and local regimes that obstruct coordinated investigation and prosecution (Mazzotta, 2011, p. 11),

technical capacity

note that some States “lack the technical wherewithal” to police activities on their territory (Huang, 2014, p. 14), and observe that incident datasets often record only events already deemed attributable, masking ambiguous cases (Maness, 2016, p. 10)

Legal

State responsibility ILC

Doctrinal tests for imputing non‑state acts to States are repeatedly flagged as mismatched to the cyber technical baseline. Canonical formulations require instruction, direction, or effective control to attribute non‑state operations ((Banks, 2017, p. 10)), and analysts argue that the ILC corpus presumes person‑ or organ‑level linkage that cyber practice cannot reliably produce (Antonopoulos, 2015, p. 2).

Due diligence

Proposals to shift presumptions—such as a rebuttable territorial presumption when an operation “emanates from within” a State—seek to address the gap but encounter judicial precedent and doctrinal resistance (Chircop, 2018, p. 4). Empirically, then, doctrinal rigor constrains wrongful attribution but leaves many harms legally orphaned.

New section

jurisdiction

Consequences For policy

Deterrence

Policy proposals therefore emphasize institutionalized, confidential evidence‑sharing and capacity building as necessary complements to technical forensics.

Attribution impossible

Many commentators argue that meeting necessity and proportionality demands will often be “exceedingly difficult” absent high confidence in attribution (Gill, 2013, p. 30)

Responses

Policy responses cluster into three partially competing pathways that the evidence weighs differently: (1) preserve high evidentiary bars while strengthening cross‑border cooperation and forensics; (2) adopt procedural or presumptive devices (e.g., rebuttable territorial presumptions or due‑diligence obligations) to lower practical costs to victims; and (3) invest in confidence‑building mechanisms (CBMs), notifications, and hotlines to manage mis‑signalling. Scholars propose due‑diligence framing and notification mechanisms that convert political claims into legal “knowledge” and create obligations to act without full human attribution (Tsagourias, 2012, p. 14), explore shifting burdens via a rebuttable presumption (Chircop, 2018, p. 4), and underscore particular CBM designs to reduce escalation (al., 2014). The evidence shows these are complementary but contested paths rather than fully reconcilable solutions.

proposals to lower evidentiary thresholds for deterrence are countervailed by warnings that such shortcuts invite mis‑attribution and unjustified escalation (Rivera, 2015, p. 1).

Policy responses cluster into three partially competing pathways that the evidence weighs differently: (1) preserve high evidentiary bars while strengthening cross‑border cooperation and forensics; (2) adopt procedural or presumptive devices (e.g., rebuttable territorial presumptions or due‑diligence obligations) to lower practical costs to victims; and (3) invest in confidence‑building mechanisms (CBMs), notifications, and hotlines to manage mis‑signalling. Scholars propose due‑diligence framing and notification mechanisms that convert political claims into legal “knowledge” and create obligations to act without full human attribution (Tsagourias, 2012, p. 14), explore shifting burdens via a rebuttable presumption (Chircop, 2018, p. 4), and underscore particular CBM designs to reduce escalation (al., 2014). The evidence shows these are complementary but contested paths rather than fully reconcilable solutions.

Across the corpus there is a clear unresolved trade‑off: preserving high attribution standards protects against wrongful coercion but results in enforcement and remedial gaps; lowering thresholds or using effects‑based tests could improve recourse but risks mis‑attribution and escalatory error. Several authors stress the limits of adopting capability‑or effects‑based approaches absent robust procedural safeguards (Antonopoulos, 2015, p. 2), and others emphasize that deterrence strategies begin with attribution, thereby framing the political calculus states face when choosing between secrecy, public naming, or institutional remedies (Buchanan, 2014, p. 3). Technical scepticism about traceability thus trades enforcement efficacy against the heightened risk of diplomatic and kinetic mis‑steps (Ney, 2015, p. 7).

Synthesis across paragraphs: the strongest regularities are that technical anonymity, routability through intermediaries, and evidentiary latency impose persistent attribution shortfalls that frustrate the person‑ and State‑focused premises of State‑responsibility law (Hobe, 2018, p. 12) and that doctrinal control tests are often empirically unattainable (Banks, 2017, p. 10). Main disagreements concern remedies: whether to preserve strict attribution and invest in institutions, or to recalibrate thresholds (with safeguards) to restore deterrence.

children.edited_html:
Attribution as Bottleneck: Cyber Attribution Research Discourse, 1999–2009

Abstract

Between 1999 and 2009, cyber attribution was repeatedly treated as the hinge on which legality, strategy, and escalation management turned. Across early “information warfare” and computer network attack (CNA) literatures, authors confronted a persistent asymmetry: operations could be conducted remotely and transnationally, yet responsibility could remain uncertain at decision time. This paper provides a historical analysis of attribution discourse in that decade using a structured corpus of coded excerpts from legal, policy, and technical writings. We find three recurring patterns. First, a dominant “attribution-as-gateway” framing positioned self-defence and countermeasures as normatively available only when responsibility could be linked to a state or its agents. Second, the same corpus catalogued structural constraints—multi-jurisdiction routing, compromised intermediaries, and deception—that made rapid, high-confidence attribution difficult, thereby destabilising necessity and proportionality reasoning. Third, proposed remedies focused less on perfect identification than on procedural and institutional architectures: investigative cooperation, mutual legal assistance, extradition, and verification analogies, alongside proposals to narrow protected interests (critical infrastructure) or to soften legal consequences for good-faith responses under uncertainty. Methodologically, every cited sentence in this paper is verified against the citation anchor’s evidence snippet (the anchor title attribute), enabling auditable reconstruction of 1999–2009 debate trajectories.

Keywords

cyber attribution; information warfare; computer network attack; international law; self-defence; countermeasures; due diligence; evidence; deception; cooperation

1. Introduction

Early writing on cyber conflict already highlighted how disruptive activity could be observable while responsibility remained opaque. Joyner describes hackers who disrupted NATO’s e-mail communications system by overloading it, while noting that the hackers’ identities were not determined (Joyner, 2001, p. 18).

This attribution gap mattered because much of the 1999–2009 discourse treated attribution as a prerequisite for lawful cross-border responses. Hoisington emphasises that the international law of self-defence generally does not justify acts of active defence across international borders unless the provocation can be attributed to an agent of the state concerned (Hoisington, 2009, p. 14).

The research problem addressed here is therefore not whether attribution is “hard” in the abstract, but how the 1999–2009 literature used technical and evidentiary constraints to argue for (or against) particular legal thresholds and governance designs. A secondary gap is that these arguments were advanced across partially disconnected legal, policy, and technical discussions, making it easy to miss the decade’s core fault lines.

This paper’s main findings are threefold. First, the decade’s discourse consistently positioned attribution as a gateway to self-defence, countermeasures, and collective security narratives. Second, the same literature documented mechanisms—compromised intermediaries, multi-jurisdiction routing, and deception—that made rapid, high-confidence attribution structurally difficult. Third, proposed solutions clustered around cooperation and procedure (rather than “perfect forensics”), but were constrained by sovereignty, secrecy, and intrusiveness concerns.

Contributions

  • Reconstructs the principal debate in 1999–2009 attribution discourse: strict state-link requirements versus governance models that redistribute responsibility through cooperation and omission-based duties.
  • Maps recurring attribution patterns (latency, false leads, deception, and non-state actor pathways) to the legal concepts they were used to contest (necessity, proportionality, and state responsibility).
  • Systematises the decade’s solution repertoire (mutual legal assistance, extradition, verification analogies, and framework conventions) and clarifies why these proposals were viewed as both necessary and politically constrained.
  • Provides an auditable synthesis method that verifies each cited claim against the citation anchor’s evidence snippet (the anchor title attribute) and removes in-paragraph citation duplication.

Section 2 summarises the period’s relevant related work. Sections 3–5 specify the scope, assumptions, and synthesis method. Section 6 presents results (the reconstructed debate and patterns). Sections 7–9 discuss implications, limitations, and conclude.

2. Background / Related Work

The 1999–2009 literature repeatedly characterised the legal environment as unsettled. Johnson states that “at present there is no such law,” and that relevant rules can only accumulate from state practice as events unfold over time (Johnson, 2002, p. 16). In parallel, commentators noted that prevailing international law did not explicitly address cyber warfare (Schaap, 2009, p. 5).

Authors also sought to describe cyber operations in operational terms. Schaap characterises computer network operations (together with electronic warfare) as actions used to attack, deceive, degrade, disrupt, deny, exploit, and defend electronic information and infrastructure (Schaap, 2009, p. 10). Others highlighted the uncertain fit with existing weapons categories: Dinstein notes that CNAs were not incorporated in any present list of proscribed weapons under the lex lata (Dinstein, 2002, p. 16).

Technological features were treated as normative arguments, not mere context. Johnson observes that geography had ceased to be relevant for the security of internet-connected (or radio-accessible) information systems (Johnson, 2002, p. 4), and that developing at least some capability to interfere with other nations’ information systems was relatively cheap and easy compared to other modern weapons systems (Johnson, 2002, p. 4). This combination—global reach and low barriers—sharpened the perceived stakes of attribution and evidentiary standards.

3. Model / Threat Model / Assumptions

What “attribution” means in this period. In the 1999–2009 discourse, attribution typically meant (i) establishing the genuine identity of an attacker and (ii) linking the relevant conduct to a legally relevant actor (often a state or a state-linked agent). Dinstein frames “establishing the genuine identity of the attacker” and attributing the act to the real (as distinct from apparent) actor as a major challenge at the then-current stage of technological development (Dinstein, 2002, p. 9). Operationally, Todd emphasises that, because a state needs to know against which state to exercise self-defence, developing reliable attribution posed a difficulty in applying “age-old laws and methods” to cyberspace (Todd, 2009, p. 36). Doctrinally, Kulesza summarises a two-step responsibility analysis: identify the international rule violated and then attribute the action to a particular state (Kulesza, 2009, p. 10).

Threat model: uncertainty by design and by circumstance. Hoisington argues that cyberspace enables remote attacks and anonymity such that perpetrators of cyberattacks are likely to go unidentified (Hoisington, 2009, p. 14). Dinstein observes that, in the state of the art, it was often unclear who originated a CNA (Dinstein, 2002, p. 13). He further notes that a seemingly source server may have been manipulated by the true assailants who routed the attack through it (Dinstein, 2002, p. 9).

Cross-border routing and jurisdictional friction. Todd stresses that communications can “hop” through several countries, making it nearly impossible for a state to develop attribution without first violating other states’ cyber infrastructure and jurisdiction (Todd, 2009, p. 36). As a workaround, Todd describes states sending requests for assistance to cooperating states in order to “hop back” through IP addresses without violating another state’s cyberspace (Todd, 2009, p. 36). Consistent with this, Condron argues that geographical borders are almost meaningless in cyberspace because cyberspace lacks borders in the traditional sense (Condron, 2007, p. 8), and that routing may cross physical borders even when transmission is between domestically situated entities (Condron, 2007, p. 8).

Evidence manipulation and deception. Kulesza provides a concrete illustration of misleading technical traces: IP analysis traced attacks to a service provider in Texas, but further investigation showed that provider was itself a victim of an attack initiated from Israeli territory (Kulesza, 2009, p. 4). Schaap highlights that increasingly sophisticated digital photo manipulation can make it very challenging—and sometimes impossible—to discern whether objects in a photograph were actually there when the photo was taken (Schaap, 2009, p. 19). He also notes the possibility of cloning speech patterns using a short digital recording (Schaap, 2009, p. 20). Hollis describes military deception as using information technology and computer networks to deliberately mislead adversary decision makers (Hollis, 2007, p. 9), and Kodar characterises a CNA ruse as communicating incorrect information (for example, forging information in an enemy reconnaissance database) (Kodar, 2009, p. 17).

Scope assumptions. This paper is limited to 1999–2009 discourse. The corpus is the set of coded excerpts contained in the 1999–2009 node of the provided coder-state export, and “evidence” refers to what is explicitly supported by the citation anchors’ title attributes.

4. Methodology / System Design

We treat the provided coder-state export as a structured qualitative dataset. Each item node contains an excerpt and one or more citation anchors; each anchor’s title attribute provides a short evidence snippet. Our synthesis method follows five steps: (1) traverse the 1999–2009 node tree and collect all included excerpts and their anchors; (2) recluster excerpts into the paper’s mandatory outline (legal thresholds, attribution constraints, actor models, and solution proposals); (3) draft a cohesive narrative that prefers in-period terminology (“information warfare,” CNA, computer network operations) and avoids anachronistic framings; (4) enforce anchor-based verification so that every sentence containing a citation anchor is a faithful paraphrase of that anchor’s evidence snippet; and (5) deduplicate anchors within each paragraph when the same underlying citation is repeated.

Reproducibility is supported by the fact that all claims tied to citations are auditable: the reader can compare each cited sentence to the anchor title evidence snippet.

5. Experimental Setup / Data / Evaluation

Corpus. Within the 1999–2009 folder, the dataset contains 107 coded item excerpts organised under 10 top-level thematic folders. Across these excerpts, we observe 325 citation anchors pointing to 193 distinct quoted snippets, spanning 14 unique cited works (years: 2001, 2002, 2007, 2009).

Inclusion and exclusion. Only material within the 1999–2009 folder is used for the paper narrative. Content outside this period remains in the coder-state file but is quarantined from the paper’s argument.

Evaluation criteria. We evaluate internal validity by (i) anchor-title fidelity (every cited sentence matches its anchor’s evidence snippet) and (ii) citation hygiene (no redundant repetition of the same citation within a paragraph). Because this is a historical-method paper, “performance” is assessed as traceability and argumentative coherence rather than predictive accuracy.

6. Results

6.1 The main debate: attribution as prerequisite versus governance under uncertainty

A dominant “strict prerequisite” position treated attribution as the gateway to lawful cross-border response. Joyner argues that when a state can link a cyber-attack to a foreign government, a forcible response may be necessary either to defend against an ongoing attack or to prevent future attacks (Joyner, 2001, p. 27). Hoisington similarly emphasises that acts of active defence across borders are generally not justified unless the provocation can be attributed to an agent of the state concerned (Hoisington, 2009, p. 14).

This prerequisite logic interacted with time and intent constraints. Jensen argues that, because of the instantaneous nature of CNAs, the right to respond must accrue immediately despite traditional obstacles including attribution, characterization (intent), and the inviolability of neutrals (Jensen, 2002, p. 4). Todd nevertheless cautions that a delayed response weakens a state’s claim of necessity to defend itself (Todd, 2009, p. 35). Hoisington states that in order to respond with force, a victim state must first identify the attacker’s intentions as hostile (Hoisington, 2009, p. 14).

A competing move in the 1999–2009 discourse was to redesign doctrine for uncertain attribution. Hoisington argues that to address the unique nature of cyberwarfare, international law should protect states that initiate a good-faith response to an attack (acting in cyber self-defence) without first attributing and characterizing the attack (Hoisington, 2009, p. 2).

6.2 Threshold management: aggregation, countermeasures, and actor identification

The corpus shows repeated efforts to manage thresholds without abandoning actor-linked legality. Dinstein argues that a state suffering a series of small-scale attacks may respond to them aggregately in a single large-scale forcible counter-measure (Dinstein, 2002, p. 11). Jensen emphasises that countermeasures must respond to a previous international wrongful act of another state and must be directed against that state (Jensen, 2002, p. 15).

6.3 Attribution constraints: routing, intermediaries, and manipulated evidence

The discourse offered a consistent catalogue of attribution failure modes. Hoisington argues that opportunities for remote attacks and attacker anonymity mean perpetrators are likely to go unidentified (Hoisington, 2009, p. 14). Dinstein similarly observes that it was often unclear who originated a CNA (Dinstein, 2002, p. 13), and he notes that a seemingly source server may have been manipulated by true assailants who routed the attack through it (Dinstein, 2002, p. 9). Smith argues that difficulty in attributing an information operation to its true source might provide forces sufficient cover regarding the origin of the attack (Smith, 2002, p. 13).

Cross-border routing linked attribution to sovereignty and cooperation. Todd notes that attacks may hop through multiple countries, making it nearly impossible to develop attribution without first violating other states’ cyber infrastructure and jurisdiction (Todd, 2009, p. 36). He therefore describes states seeking assistance from cooperating states to hop back through IP addresses while avoiding cyberspace violations (Todd, 2009, p. 36). Condron argues that cyberspace has no borders in the traditional sense (Condron, 2007, p. 8) and that routing may cross physical borders even for domestic-to-domestic transmissions (Condron, 2007, p. 8). He adds that investigating an attack may take days or even months (Condron, 2007, p. 17).

Evidence manipulation was treated as a first-order threat. Kulesza’s example—Texas attribution later revealed as secondary victimisation from Israeli territory—illustrates how initial technical traces can point to the wrong jurisdiction (Kulesza, 2009, p. 4). Schaap highlights sophisticated image manipulation that can be impossible to detect (Schaap, 2009, p. 19) and the cloning of speech patterns from a short recording (Schaap, 2009, p. 20). Hollis defines military deception as using information technology and computer networks to deliberately mislead decision makers (Hollis, 2007, p. 9), and Kodar describes ruses such as forging information in an enemy reconnaissance database (Kodar, 2009, p. 17).

Doyle argues that in the case of a physical attack against a computer network asset itself (such as destroying a satellite), the source and location can probably be pinpointed (Doyle, 2002, p. 9).

6.4 Actor models: states, proxies, and omission-based responsibility

A recurring cleavage in 1999–2009 writing concerns who can be an attacker and how international law can follow. Jensen argues that, because hacker tools are cheap, accessible, and easy to weaponize, disruptive attacks can be perpetrated not only by nation-states but also by opposition groups, ideological radicals, terrorist organisations, and individuals (Jensen, 2002, p. 8). Smith argues that a treaty limiting information operations by nations does not address the problem of terrorists or hackers (Smith, 2002, p. 14). Joyner notes that a foreign state could hire mercenary-like individuals to carry out an information-warfare attack without attribution to state sponsorship (Joyner, 2001, p. 4).

Todd defines a cyberspace attack as occurring when a state knowingly uses, or knowingly acquiesces to, an entity under its legal control or within its territory using a cyberspace weapon against another state’s people or property (Todd, 2009, p. 24). Kulesza emphasises that a state may be held responsible not only for actions but also for omissions, in particular failure to exercise due diligence (Kulesza, 2009, p. 11). Hollis recounts Estonia and Russia sparring over duty to deny safe haven and an obligation to assist in locating responsible actors under a bilateral mutual legal assistance treaty (Hollis, 2007, p. 5).

6.5 Solution repertoire: cooperation, legal assistance, verification, and rule design

Johnson argues that effective international cooperation in tracing computer network attacks to their origin would greatly expedite attribution of state-sponsored CNA (Johnson, 2002, p. 7). He also warns that cooperation has been frustrated by unwillingness to cooperate, lack of domestic authority, missing procedures and points of contact, and extradition problems (Johnson, 2002, p. 5). Franzese proposes agreements to recognise sovereignty in cyberspace, assist trace-back to original sources, identify specific responsible actors, and prosecute or extradite them (Franzese, 2009, p. 42).

Kodar argues that if legal assistance agreements are to fight cybercrime effectively, they need explicit scope covering cybercrime (or crimes generally) (Kodar, 2009, p. 18). He notes that where states have not entered extradition agreements, they have neither a duty nor a domestic legal basis to extradite a person to another state (Kodar, 2009, p. 18).

Hollis suggests that states could follow arms-control precedents by establishing verification procedures in which other states or a designated non-state actor can examine compliance with information-operations obligations (Hollis, 2007, p. 40). He proposes negotiating a framework convention that sets common principles and allows later protocols or amendments to supply operational rules (Hollis, 2007, p. 39). Johnson argues it is difficult to imagine confidence-building agreements for CNA capabilities because they would require exceptionally intrusive access to national computer systems (Johnson, 2002, p. 11), and he states that adoption of a multilateral convention restricting state action relating to information warfare is extremely unlikely anytime soon (Johnson, 2002, p. 13).

Condron argues that the Department of Defense lacked an organisation dedicated to cyber defence of critical infrastructure (Condron, 2007, p. 10). He proposes limiting jus ad bellum measures to defence of critical infrastructure that a nation has pre-selected and publicly disseminated prior to an incident (Condron, 2007, p. 20). Hoisington argues that the international community should promulgate a list of critical national infrastructure that a state may protect with active defence measures (Hoisington, 2009, p. 16). He calls for the establishment of clear and appropriate rules of engagement for cyber defence activities (Hoisington, 2009, p. 9).

6.6 Classification, intent, and escalation risk

Doyle argues that absent a conventional attack component, manipulation or intrusion by itself does not automatically indicate hostile intent (Doyle, 2002, p. 6). Todd notes that acts deemed espionage will not trigger a state’s right to self-defence because espionage does not violate international law (Todd, 2009, p. 31).

Hoisington reports Schmitt’s six criteria for delimiting economic and political coercion from the use of armed force: severity, immediacy, directness, invasiveness, measurability, and presumptive legitimacy (Hoisington, 2009, p. 11).

Doyle argues that damage or destruction of a dual-use military and civilian satellite would raise serious issues for high-tech forces dependent on satellites for military and commercial purposes (Doyle, 2002, p. 12). Kodar argues that civil and military structures use the same technical facilities, creating a danger that a CNA will transform from one structure to another with serious consequences (Kodar, 2009, p. 5). Schaap claims that NATO did not define cyber-attacks as a clear military action, meaning Article V collective self-defence would not automatically extend to the attacked country (Schaap, 2009, p. 25).

Smith argues that lack of attribution characteristics might violate existing law of war rules concerning perfidy, implying a new treaty is not required for that specific purpose (Smith, 2002, p. 15).

7. Discussion

The 1999–2009 attribution discourse can be read as an attempt to reconcile three pressures. First, self-defence and countermeasure logics were widely treated as actor-linked: the legitimacy of responsive action was argued to depend on identifying a responsible party and, often, a state nexus. Second, technical realities were described as adversarial: routing through intermediaries, compromised servers, and deception meant that attribution was contestable and time-consuming. Third, institutional proposals confronted sovereignty, secrecy, and intrusiveness barriers: cooperation and verification were advanced as necessary, yet simultaneously described as difficult to implement.

Two families of solutions illustrate this tension. One family sought to make strict attribution feasible through cooperation channels (mutual legal assistance, extradition, and trace-back assistance), sometimes with verification analogies. A second family sought to manage uncertainty by adjusting rules: narrowing which interests justify force (critical infrastructure lists), clarifying rules of engagement, or affording legal protection for good-faith responses when attribution and intent cannot be established quickly. Hoisington argues that cyberwarfare technology makes it nearly impossible to attribute attacks to a specific source or to characterise intent behind them (Hoisington, 2009, p. 15).

Jensen notes that active responses may include in-kind rejoinders or “hack-back” features that reflect similar damage back to the sender or otherwise respond (Jensen, 2002, p. 26).

8. Limitations

This paper is limited to the corpus represented in the provided coder-state export’s 1999–2009 folder; it does not claim comprehensive coverage of all publications in the decade. The synthesis relies on anchor-title evidence snippets, which are necessarily short and may omit surrounding nuance in the underlying sources. Because the objective is historical reconstruction of discourse, the analysis evaluates traceability and coherence rather than the empirical accuracy of any particular doctrinal prediction.

9. Conclusion

From 1999 to 2009, attribution was repeatedly portrayed as both gateway and bottleneck: gateway because lawful force and countermeasures were argued to depend on identifying a responsible actor, and bottleneck because technical and evidentiary constraints made such identification slow, contestable, and politically risky. The decade’s literature linked these constraints to proposals centred on cooperation and procedure—mutual legal assistance, extradition, and verification analogies—while warning that sovereignty and intrusiveness would limit implementation. It also produced rule-design proposals to manage uncertainty (critical infrastructure lists, rules of engagement, and good-faith response protections). Overall, the period’s discourse framed attribution as a socio-technical governance problem in which evidentiary thresholds, institutional channels, and escalation risk are inseparable.

The main issue and debate around legal

Self-defense and Armed attack debate

Between 1999 and 2009, our dataset shows an important concern with cyber operations and what they represent to international relations with ups and downs. As discussed briefly in the introduction, the 90s experienced a singular surge of cyber incidents, which were not per se cyberattacks, but result of experiments of computer scientist/students. The surge was on flood attacks, creating of botnets and the beginning of Deny of service along with its techniques to counter theme. However, these types of incidents reached its apex in 2001 with Iloveyou bug representing effects of cyber incidents could reach the entire globe.The expansion of cyberspace was become increasingly integral to government, military, and civilian functions.

It was in this dominant technical background that the literature of international relations start to think about cyber incidents. (Schmitt 1999) was pioneer in highlighting the fundamental question around cyber operations and law, but the emerging preoccupation with cyber operations lost track after 9/11. That explains why in our dataset, there is this hiatus in cyber conflict literature discussing cyber attribution. Only after the attacks on Estonia in 2007, studies regain attention with an increase of 70%. This first phase of studies, succeeded in bringing to attention two concerns a threshold question rooted in the UN Charter: can a cyber operation ever amount to an “armed attack” that justifies self-defence? Secondly, how to respond to cyber threads effectively?Debate:

The backdrop of the debate was the integration of technology into the government, business and individuals as well as the augment of attacks emergence. Particularly, although the 2007 was the wake up and most accurate representation of fears of this decade, the disruption, data theft, inoperability of services and for example power plants, water planters and so on were a preoccupation of scholars at the point where in 1999, Aquila wrote “cyber war is coming”. It was not rare comparisons with such as “cyber harbours” as almost III world war. As a result, must of the debate was legal language translatability. In case of a cyber-attack, how to define an attack, aggression, an armed attack? depriving the adversary of infrastructure that supports military operations such as electrical or communication systems (Hollis 2007, 125)

Across the lenses, then, attribution is alternately deferred (effects), discounted at the threshold (target/CNI), or streamlined to knowledge/acquiescence (instrument), while the baseline Charter view remains that force law applies “to any use of force, regardless of the weapons employed.” (Condron, 2007, p. 413 :contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}).To navigate this problem, early authors proposed three analytic lenses for evaluating cyber-attacks—each lens placed attribution in a different light. One approach was effects-based, judging cyber operations by their consequences rather than by the weapon or target. Following this view, if a computer network attack causes damage comparable to a conventional military strike, it should be treated as a use of force regardless of the tool used or the attacker’s intent. Schmitt (1999) articulated this consequences-centric test, suggesting that even a non-kinetic cyber operation qualifies as a prohibited use of force if its effects parallel those of a physical attack. A second, target-based approach prioritized the object of the cyber assault, especially if it struck critical national infrastructure. Proponents argued that penetrating systems vital to public welfare or national security inherently escalates the situation, perhaps warranting an immediate defensive response before full attribution is confirmed. In a notable early example, Jensen (2002) contended that international law should create a “safe harbor” for states to take prompt defensive action against attacks on critical infrastructure **without first attributing and characterizing the attack**, since waiting for certainty could be fatal. He even suggested that states publish a list of critical assets to put others on notice and bolster the legitimacy of reacting to attacks on those assets. The third approach was instrument-based, focusing on the means and methods of cyber attack. This perspective sought to define what counts as a cyber “weapon” or offensive act in advance, akin to how criminal law defines offenses, so that any use of such means might automatically be deemed hostile. For instance, Todd (2009) argued that we should identify and outlaw malicious cyber tools and techniques themselves, thereby simplifying attribution and legal classification: if a state deploys a recognized cyber weapon, that action can be labeled an attack without first measuring its outcome. Each model—effects, target, and instrument—handled attribution differently. The effects-based test could sidestep knowing the perpetrator’s identity by focusing on impact (though ultimately one must still find who caused the impact for accountability). The target-based test reduced the burden on attribution by justifying defensive moves when certain protected assets came under fire, effectively shifting the risk to the attacker if they chose those targets. The instrument-based approach tried to make attribution more straightforward by outlawing certain cyber techniques altogether; if those were detected in use, one could immediately attribute unlawful intent to whoever launched them. While none of these frameworks resolved the attribution challenge outright, they provided early conceptual tools for judging cyber operations under international law.

A key tension throughout this decade was the trade-off between action and certainty: should states wait for clear attribution and evidence before responding, or adapt the law to allow instantaneous defense in the face of ambiguous cyber threats? This debate often broke along the lines of “restraint” versus “urgency.” The restraint camp held that no matter how fast cyber attacks unfold, the traditional principles of necessity and proportionality – and the requirement of a definite armed attack – must govern. Scholars in this vein warned against lowering the evidentiary bar for self-defense, lest states too readily resort to force based on misidentification or fear. As one leading voice, Dinstein (2002) allowed for “interceptive” self-defense (striking an attack in progress) but only when an armed attack is clearly imminent or underway – essentially when the facts leave no doubt (“the die is cast”). He emphasized that even then, responses must be controlled by proportionality and aimed at halting or repelling the attack, not punishing the unknown perpetrator. This cautious stance implicitly required solid attribution: you must know an attack is coming or has happened, and who is responsible, before you hit back. On the other side, the urgency camp argued that cyber incursions move at network speed, potentially crippling critical systems in minutes, so insisting on ironclad attribution and state-level intent before reacting is unrealistic and dangerous. Jensen, for example, noted that a state under massive cyber assault on its power grid or financial system cannot afford to spend weeks tracing the attack while its infrastructure fails. He urged that a victim state acting in good-faith defense – using carefully calibrated countermeasures and targeting only the attacking code or server – should not be deemed in violation of international law even if it cannot yet prove who attacked it. Jensen (2002) argued that state survival might depend on “an immediate, robust, and aggressive response” and thus proposed a legal safe harbor for prompt cyber counter-attacks launched without full attribution. This viewpoint also acknowledged practical reality: often a state’s technical experts can identify that an attack is underway and even take action to block it (for example, by severing connections or disabling malicious servers) long before they can be certain who orchestrated it. The risk, of course, is that acting on partial information could hit an innocent intermediary or misidentify the source – a risk the restraint camp highlighted by pointing to the complex path of internet traffic. In essence, by the end of the 2000s the scholarly community had framed a dilemma: insisting on attribution and certainty keeps responses lawful but may leave a victim state “waiting helplessly” during a crippling cyber onslaught, whereas loosening those requirements empowers defense but runs afoul of sovereignty and legal stability if mistakes are made. This dilemma set the stage for many proposals to refine how attribution is handled in cyber law.

It was also in this moment the scaffold legal framework for cyberspace were created. The US act, convention of cybercrime budabest, European union directive

Legal commentators converge on a strong regularity: established jus ad bellum requirements—necessity, imminence, and proportionality—implicitly require reliable attribution before a state can lawfully employ force, and cyber operations routinely fail to produce that degree of proof. Multiple sources assert that the law of self‑defence \"does not justify acts of active defense across international borders unless the provocation can be attributed to an agent of the nation concerned\" and that discerning hostile intent is an additional evidentiary burden that cyber incidents often cannot meet quickly ((Hoisington, 2009, p. 14) (Joyner, 2001, p. 27) (Hoisington, 2009, p. 14)). The legal consequence is that many potentially serious CNAs fall short of the evidentiary threshold for force, producing a governance gap where operations may be harmful yet not legally actionable under present doctrine.

A consistent finding across the corpus is that attribution functions as a legal gateway that separates norm‑violation determination from remedial entitlement: authors repeatedly describe a two‑step sequence in which an affected state must first identify the breached international norm and only then attribute the offending operation to a state before remedies such as reparations or countermeasures become available ((Kulesza, 2009, p. 10)); this two‑step framing amplifies uncertainty about when an incident qualifies as an armed attack or as a lesser international wrong ((Hollis, 2007, p. 11)). Practically, commentators show that contested threshold language (e.g., what counts as \"damage,\" a \"weapon,\" or an \"armed attack\") forces states to choose interpretive approaches with very different operational consequences ((Doyle, 2002, p. 10)).

Scholars disagree about how proportionality should govern cyber countermeasures, producing a visible schism between a mission‑focused calculus and a self‑defense symmetry test: some authors treat proportionality as an operational, mission‑accomplishment judgment rather than a strict comparison of quantum of forces ((Doyle, 2002, p. 10)), whereas the jus ad bellum frame emphasizes approximate parity in \"scale and effects\" and traditional necessity/proportionality constraints ((Jensen, 2002, p. 13)). A contested doctrinal move is aggregation—treating a series of small attacks as a single large attack—which some authors endorse as legally permissible but many warn would magnify mis‑signalling and collateral risk when cyber effects cascade ((Dinstein, 2002, p. 11)). Thus, proportionality disputes become a direct driver of escalation risk when attribution is uncertain and effects are diffuse.

Across the literature, a consistent pattern is the absence of clear legal benchmarks tying technical intrusion to the international law concept of an \"armed attack,\" producing contested thresholds for when states may lawfully resort to force. Scholars offer competing framings — a multi‑criteria operational test to calibrate severity and immediacy ((Hoisington, 2009, p. 11)), while other authors advance a strict results‑oriented approach treating functionally equivalent cyber effects as uses of force; this legal debate sits atop practical exemplars of high‑end consequences that policymakers view as unambiguously armed attacks ((Jensen, 2002, p. 21)). This doctrinal uncertainty is reinforced by repeated observations that \"current international law does not explicitly address cyber warfare,\" leaving policymakers without settled normative anchors for many CNAs ((Schaap, 2009, p. 5)).

Across the literature, a consistent pattern is the absence of clear legal benchmarks tying technical intrusion to the international law concept of an \"armed attack,\" producing contested thresholds for when states may lawfully resort to force. Scholars offer competing framings — a multi‑criteria operational test to calibrate severity and immediacy ((Hoisington, 2009, p. 11)), while other authors advance a strict results‑oriented approach treating functionally equivalent cyber effects as uses of force; this legal debate sits atop practical exemplars of high‑end consequences that policymakers view as unambiguously armed attacks ((Jensen, 2002, p. 21)). This doctrinal uncertainty is reinforced by repeated observations that \"current international law does not explicitly address cyber warfare,\" leaving policymakers without settled normative anchors for many CNAs ((Schaap, 2009, p. 5)).

A pervasive technical‑legal theme is that dual‑use infrastructures convert attribution uncertainty into concrete targeting and proportionality dilemmas: telecommunications, satellites, and shared civil–military networks blur the line between legitimate military objectives and protected civilian objects. Authors point to the \"dual‑use quality\" of telecom networks and its implications for applying traditional law of armed conflict constraints ((Joyner, 2001, p. 36)). The interdependence of civil and military systems means cyber effects can spill across user groups, making proportionality and distinction judgments technically fraught ((Kodar, 2009, p. 5)). Satellite dependence illustrates the political salience of this problem because damage to dual‑use space assets produces cascading civil and military harms that complicate both legal classification and state willingness to immunize targets ((Doyle, 2002, p. 12)).

Finally, the literature identifies operational unpredictability and cascading effects as central to escalation risk: imperfect forecasting of CNA effects and knock‑on harms undercut proportionality and causation assessments, prompting calls for restrictive rules of engagement and stronger legal review before action. Analysts warn that the capacity to predict CNA damage is limited, making precision and control difficult ((Doyle, 2002, p. 13)), while other authors emphasize that many CNA problems stem from secondary or \"effects of effects\" rather than immediate direct damage ((Kodar, 2009, p. 16)). In response, commentators propose clearer ROE and anticipatory doctrines to lower decision costs, acknowledging the attendant risk that more permissive ROE could itself increase mis‑signalling if attribution is uncertain ((Hoisington, 2009, p. 9)).

Scholars repeatedly debated legal thresholds for when cyber operations amount to a 'use of force' or an armed attack and proposed competing operational tests to reduce ambiguity. One influential multi‑criteria approach foregrounds factors such as \"severity, immediacy, directness\" to distinguish coercion from armed force ((Hoisington, 2009, p. 11)), a strict results‑oriented test equates cyberacts causing physical effects with kinetic attacks ((Schaap, 2009, p. 23)), and some commentators argue doctrinally for anticipatory or good‑faith responses to address the instant nature of CNAs ((Todd, 2009, p. 9)). These competing tests reflect a clear disagreement about whether to privilege actor‑based attribution or effect‑based thresholds, and that disagreement directly shapes permissibility, timing, and escalation risk.

A recurrent and well‑supported claim is that evidentiary limits and cascading or knock‑on effects complicate proportionality and causation judgments, weakening legal foundations for measured responses. Several authors emphasise that harms from CNAs can be indirect cascades rather than direct physical consequences, making proportionality calculations unpredictable ((Kodar, 2009, p. 16)), that the precision of CNA effects cannot yet be relied upon ((Doyle, 2002, p. 13)), and that doctrinal proposals linking use‑of‑force to the \"potential to cause\" physical harm try to build a usable evidentiary bridge ((Schaap, 2009, p. 23)). The literature therefore converges on the need for cautious proportionality thresholds but diverges on how to operationalise them without unduly weakening deterrence.

Legal doctrines and jus ad bellum thresholds amplify the evidentiary costs of attribution by treating attribution as a gate to lawful countermeasures; commentators therefore urge high standards before public accusation or force. Several authors stress that linking an incident to a state is a prerequisite for force ((Joyner, 2001, p. 27)), and that international law typically requires proof of identity and intent ((Dinstein, 2002, p. 11)). The doctrinal insistence on “effective control” over proxies or on proving an organ‑level connection reiterates why states withhold sources and methods rather than publish evidence that may be legally challenged ((Schaap, 2009, p. 27)).

well-attested cluster focuses on doctrinal reforms: authors debate whether to treat computer network attacks as uses of force (thus lowering the evidentiary threshold for force-based responses) or to retain a criminal/countermeasure frame that preserves a higher burden and sequencing of responses. Some argue for reclassification that would allow more flexible anticipatory measures by emphasizing effects or target‑characteristics ((Jensen, 2002, p. 16)), while others prefer structured definitional work (criteria‑based tests or evidentiary floors) to restrict premature use of force ((Dinstein, 2002, p. 13)). Complementary proposals include multi‑criteria frameworks that trade clarity for nuance ((Hoisington, 2009, p. 11)). The literature therefore records a stable tension: doctrinal lowering of thresholds improves timeliness and deterrence but risks overbreadth and escalation unless paired with evidentiary constraints.

Jurisdiction

The problem is compounded by the observation that attribution efforts frequently require cross‑border access and sensitive forensics—steps that may themselves implicate other states' jurisdiction—so timely, conclusive attribution is often infeasible ((Joyner, 2001, p. 27) (Todd, 2009, p. 36) (Johnson, 2002, p. 7)).

 Commentators also emphasize that cyberspace reduces the salience of geography — \"geography has ceased to be relevant\" for connected systems — thereby creating overlapping jurisdictional claims and enforcement frictions that complicate cross‑border evidence collection ((Johnson, 2002, p. 4))

A technical‑evidentiary cluster shows durable constraints on attribution: the global ubiquity of similar platforms and software, plus use of proxies or hired operatives, routinely degrades attribution confidence and thereby increases the political cost of responding. Multiple authors highlight how \"comparable equipment\" across jurisdictions aids CNA design and obscures origin ((Johnson, 2002, p. 4)),

Cross‑border legal and institutional frictions repeatedly appear as procedural barriers: countries control forensic data on their territory and mutual assistance is often slow or withheld, creating chain‑of‑custody and admissibility problems. Multiple studies observe that overseas investigations “can only be accomplished if there is cooperation between the involved states,” and that unwilling or unauthorized partners frustrate forensic follow‑up ((Todd, 2009, p. 28); (Johnson, 2002, p. 5)). Proposals to “hop back” through cooperating ISPs illustrate stepwise tracing workflows that preserve sovereignty but introduce delay and evidentiary exposure ((Todd, 2009, p. 36)).

Evidentiary failure

In practice the evidentiary shortfall is not merely academic: researchers traced espionage hosts to a country but explicitly \"cautioned against concluding\" government involvement, showing how technical nuance converts into legal ambiguity ((Franzese, 2009, p. 4) (Kodar, 2009, p. 10) (Schaap, 2009, p. 27)).

Burden of proof lowering

Scholars debate doctrinal remedies—some recommend lowering the burden by emphasizing state due diligence rather than a strict state‑actor link, while others reject relaxed thresholds as likely to cause mis‑signalling. Proponents of a due‑diligence approach argue that \"state responsibility must be based on a due diligence requirement\" and that obligations to investigate and prevent operations originating in a state's territory could reduce impunity ((Kulesza, 2009, p. 13) (Kulesza, 2009, p. 13) (Kodar, 2009, p. 10)). Critics counter that relaxing attribution rules risks wrongful coercion because countermeasures against conduits or intermediaries may be \"counterproductive, as well as unlawful,\" and that erroneous or premature responses could escalate conflicts ((Dinstein, 2002, p. 9) (Jensen, 2002, p. 27) (Smith, 2002, p. 13)).

Attribution as a prerequesite for law

A consistent finding across the corpus is that attribution functions as a legal gateway that separates norm‑violation determination from remedial entitlement: authors repeatedly describe a two‑step sequence in which an affected state must first identify the breached international norm and only then attribute the offending operation to a state before remedies such as reparations or countermeasures become available ((Kulesza, 2009, p. 10));

State Responsibility

The literature shows two principal doctrinal pathways to state responsibility—direct organ action and control/acquiescence over proxies—and explains how omissions and domestic prosecution choices recalibrate international exposure. Authors emphasize the classic imputability rule requiring a state organ acting in that capacity or a showing of overall control to treat proxy conduct as state action ((Dinstein, 2002, p. 6); (Dinstein, 2002, p. 6))

Authors across the decade repeatedly note political obstacles to binding multilateral rule‑making and propose a mix of domestic and cooperative remedies while flagging trade‑offs. Several argue for initiating an international debate on how state responsibility principles apply to cyber threats ((Kulesza, 2009, p. 13)), while others urge bilateral or coalition measures—recognition of cybersovereignty, cooperative tracing, or mutual assistance on prosecution—that are politically more feasible ((Franzese, 2009, p. 42)). At the same time, the literature records scepticism that comprehensive conventions would emerge quickly, stressing practical and sovereignty-based barriers to rapid global rules ((Johnson, 2002, p. 13)).

Due dligence

The literature shows two principal doctrinal pathways to state responsibility—direct organ action and control/acquiescence over proxies—and explains how omissions and domestic prosecution choices recalibrate international exposure. Authors emphasize the classic imputability rule requiring a state organ acting in that capacity or a showing of overall control to treat proxy conduct as state action ((Dinstein, 2002, p. 6); (Dinstein, 2002, p. 6)). Complementing this, authors argue a state's failure to exercise due diligence or to prosecute perpetrators can itself constitute an internationally wrongful omission, potentially justifying countermeasures by victims ((Kulesza, 2009, p. 11)). The result is an evidentiary and policy calculus in which domestic prosecutorial choices carry external signaling consequences ((Kulesza, 2009, p. 13)).

However, these types of incidents reached its apex in 2001 with Iloveyou bug representing effects of cyber incidents could reach the entire globe.The expansion of cyberspace was become increasingly integral to government, military, and civilian functions.

It was in this dominant technical background that the literature of international relations start to think about cyber incidents. (Schmitt 1999) was pioneer in highlighting the fundamental question around cyber operations and law, but the emerging preoccupation with cyber operations lost track after 9/11. That explains why in our dataset, there is this hiatus in cyber conflict literature discussing cyber attribution. Only after the attacks on Estonia in 2007, studies regain attention with an increase of 70%. This first phase of studies, succeeded in bringing to attention two concerns a threshold question rooted in the UN Charter: can a cyber operation ever amount to an “armed attack” that justifies self-defence? Secondly, how to respond to cyber threads effectively?Debate:

The backdrop of the debate was the integration of technology into the government, business and individuals as well as the augment of attacks emergence. Particularly, although the 2007 was the wake up and most accurate representation of fears of this decade, the disruption, data theft, inoperability of services and for example power plants, water planters and so on were a preoccupation of scholars at the point where in 1999, Aquila wrote “cyber war is coming”. It was not rare comparisons with such as “cyber harbours” as almost III world war. As a result, must of the debate was legal language translatability. In case of a cyber-attack, how to define an attack, aggression, an armed attack? depriving the adversary of infrastructure that supports military operations such as electrical or communication systems (Hollis 2007, 125)

Across the lenses, then, attribution is alternately deferred (effects), discounted at the threshold (target/CNI), or streamlined to knowledge/acquiescence (instrument), while the baseline Charter view remains that force law applies “to any use of force, regardless of the weapons employed.” (Condron, 2007, p. 413 :contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}).To navigate this problem, early authors proposed three analytic lenses for evaluating cyber-attacks—each lens placed attribution in a different light. One approach was effects-based, judging cyber operations by their consequences rather than by the weapon or target. Following this view, if a computer network attack causes damage comparable to a conventional military strike, it should be treated as a use of force regardless of the tool used or the attacker’s intent. Schmitt (1999) articulated this consequences-centric test, suggesting that even a non-kinetic cyber operation qualifies as a prohibited use of force if its effects parallel those of a physical attack. A second, target-based approach prioritized the object of the cyber assault, especially if it struck critical national infrastructure. Proponents argued that penetrating systems vital to public welfare or national security inherently escalates the situation, perhaps warranting an immediate defensive response before full attribution is confirmed. In a notable early example, Jensen (2002) contended that international law should create a “safe harbor” for states to take prompt defensive action against attacks on critical infrastructure **without first attributing and characterizing the attack**, since waiting for certainty could be fatal. He even suggested that states publish a list of critical assets to put others on notice and bolster the legitimacy of reacting to attacks on those assets. The third approach was instrument-based, focusing on the means and methods of cyber attack. This perspective sought to define what counts as a cyber “weapon” or offensive act in advance, akin to how criminal law defines offenses, so that any use of such means might automatically be deemed hostile. For instance, Todd (2009) argued that we should identify and outlaw malicious cyber tools and techniques themselves, thereby simplifying attribution and legal classification: if a state deploys a recognized cyber weapon, that action can be labeled an attack without first measuring its outcome. Each model—effects, target, and instrument—handled attribution differently. The effects-based test could sidestep knowing the perpetrator’s identity by focusing on impact (though ultimately one must still find who caused the impact for accountability). The target-based test reduced the burden on attribution by justifying defensive moves when certain protected assets came under fire, effectively shifting the risk to the attacker if they chose those targets. The instrument-based approach tried to make attribution more straightforward by outlawing certain cyber techniques altogether; if those were detected in use, one could immediately attribute unlawful intent to whoever launched them. While none of these frameworks resolved the attribution challenge outright, they provided early conceptual tools for judging cyber operations under international law.

A key tension throughout this decade was the trade-off between action and certainty: should states wait for clear attribution and evidence before responding, or adapt the law to allow instantaneous defense in the face of ambiguous cyber threats? This debate often broke along the lines of “restraint” versus “urgency.” The restraint camp held that no matter how fast cyber attacks unfold, the traditional principles of necessity and proportionality – and the requirement of a definite armed attack – must govern. Scholars in this vein warned against lowering the evidentiary bar for self-defense, lest states too readily resort to force based on misidentification or fear. As one leading voice, Dinstein (2002) allowed for “interceptive” self-defense (striking an attack in progress) but only when an armed attack is clearly imminent or underway – essentially when the facts leave no doubt (“the die is cast”). He emphasized that even then, responses must be controlled by proportionality and aimed at halting or repelling the attack, not punishing the unknown perpetrator. This cautious stance implicitly required solid attribution: you must know an attack is coming or has happened, and who is responsible, before you hit back. On the other side, the urgency camp argued that cyber incursions move at network speed, potentially crippling critical systems in minutes, so insisting on ironclad attribution and state-level intent before reacting is unrealistic and dangerous. Jensen, for example, noted that a state under massive cyber assault on its power grid or financial system cannot afford to spend weeks tracing the attack while its infrastructure fails. He urged that a victim state acting in good-faith defense – using carefully calibrated countermeasures and targeting only the attacking code or server – should not be deemed in violation of international law even if it cannot yet prove who attacked it. Jensen (2002) argued that state survival might depend on “an immediate, robust, and aggressive response” and thus proposed a legal safe harbor for prompt cyber counter-attacks launched without full attribution. This viewpoint also acknowledged practical reality: often a state’s technical experts can identify that an attack is underway and even take action to block it (for example, by severing connections or disabling malicious servers) long before they can be certain who orchestrated it. The risk, of course, is that acting on partial information could hit an innocent intermediary or misidentify the source – a risk the restraint camp highlighted by pointing to the complex path of internet traffic. In essence, by the end of the 2000s the scholarly community had framed a dilemma: insisting on attribution and certainty keeps responses lawful but may leave a victim state “waiting helplessly” during a crippling cyber onslaught, whereas loosening those requirements empowers defense but runs afoul of sovereignty and legal stability if mistakes are made. This dilemma set the stage for many proposals to refine how attribution is handled in cyber law.

Legal commentators converge on a strong regularity: established jus ad bellum requirements—necessity, imminence, and proportionality—implicitly require reliable attribution before a state can lawfully employ force, and cyber operations routinely fail to produce that degree of proof. Multiple sources assert that the law of self‑defence \"does not justify acts of active defense across international borders unless the provocation can be attributed to an agent of the nation concerned\" and that discerning hostile intent is an additional evidentiary burden that cyber incidents often cannot meet quickly ((Hoisington, 2009, p. 14) (Joyner, 2001, p. 27) (Hoisington, 2009, p. 14)). The legal consequence is that many potentially serious CNAs fall short of the evidentiary threshold for force, producing a governance gap where operations may be harmful yet not legally actionable under present doctrine.

A consistent finding across the corpus is that attribution functions as a legal gateway that separates norm‑violation determination from remedial entitlement: authors repeatedly describe a two‑step sequence in which an affected state must first identify the breached international norm and only then attribute the offending operation to a state before remedies such as reparations or countermeasures become available ((Kulesza, 2009, p. 10)); this two‑step framing amplifies uncertainty about when an incident qualifies as an armed attack or as a lesser international wrong ((Hollis, 2007, p. 11)). Practically, commentators show that contested threshold language (e.g., what counts as \"damage,\" a \"weapon,\" or an \"armed attack\") forces states to choose interpretive approaches with very different operational consequences ((Doyle, 2002, p. 10)).

Scholars disagree about how proportionality should govern cyber countermeasures, producing a visible schism between a mission‑focused calculus and a self‑defense symmetry test: some authors treat proportionality as an operational, mission‑accomplishment judgment rather than a strict comparison of quantum of forces ((Doyle, 2002, p. 10)), whereas the jus ad bellum frame emphasizes approximate parity in \"scale and effects\" and traditional necessity/proportionality constraints ((Jensen, 2002, p. 13)). A contested doctrinal move is aggregation—treating a series of small attacks as a single large attack—which some authors endorse as legally permissible but many warn would magnify mis‑signalling and collateral risk when cyber effects cascade ((Dinstein, 2002, p. 11)). Thus, proportionality disputes become a direct driver of escalation risk when attribution is uncertain and effects are diffuse.

Across the literature, a consistent pattern is the absence of clear legal benchmarks tying technical intrusion to the international law concept of an \"armed attack,\" producing contested thresholds for when states may lawfully resort to force. Scholars offer competing framings — a multi‑criteria operational test to calibrate severity and immediacy ((Hoisington, 2009, p. 11)), while other authors advance a strict results‑oriented approach treating functionally equivalent cyber effects as uses of force; this legal debate sits atop practical exemplars of high‑end consequences that policymakers view as unambiguously armed attacks ((Jensen, 2002, p. 21)). This doctrinal uncertainty is reinforced by repeated observations that \"current international law does not explicitly address cyber warfare,\" leaving policymakers without settled normative anchors for many CNAs ((Schaap, 2009, p. 5)).
